header.title: GEMATRIA: A Preliminary Investigation of The Cabala contained in the Coptic Gnostic Books and of a similar Gematria in the Greek text of the New Testament

central_thesis: The central thesis is that a system of numerical and geometrical symbolism (Gematria) is embedded within the Coptic Gnostic Books and the Greek New Testament, revealing a 'True Gnosis' or esoteric teaching. This system uses the numerical values of Greek and Hebrew letters to express doctrinal significance, demonstrate aeonial relationships, and encode geometric formulae. The authors argue that this hidden wisdom connects theological concepts with architectural principles, offering a deeper understanding of divine mysteries and the structure of the cosmos, which they believe was consciously incorporated by ancient compilers of sacred texts.

structure_content.summary: The authors propose that recovering the 'Key of Knowledge' through Gematria will reveal a real Gnosis in the Apostolic Church, bridging Christian theology with the architectural and geometrical symbolism found in Gnostic texts and Scripture. They suggest that Jesus, as a 'Carpenter or Builder', subtly embedded principles of creation (Aeons) into his teachings.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Method of Gematria: Or Association of Letter and Number. A Brief Description.
structure_content.summary: This section describes the historical origins of Gematria in Syro-Phoenician, Greek, and Hebrew systems around the 5th-3rd centuries B.C. It explains that alphabets also served as numerals in a denary system. The authors assert that the meticulous construction of these languages, along with the peculiar reverence for letters' mystical values and symbolic teachings (Number, Sound, Form), indicates intentional design rather than chance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter I. A Brief Outline of the Gematria.
structure_content.summary: This chapter elaborates on the premise that Gematria reveals a hidden Gnosis within Coptic Gnostic Books (Pistis Sophia, Books of IEOU) and the New Testament. It demonstrates how numerical values of names and terms (e.g., Nero = 666, ΚΗΦΑΣ = 729 = 9³) encode geometrical formulae and aeonial relationships. The method connects sacred names to geometric shapes (e.g., altar as a cube, ΤΟ ΘΥΣΙΑΣΤΗΡΙΟΝ = 1728 = 12³), suggesting a coherent teaching system.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter II. The Existence of the Gnosis.
structure_content.summary: The authors argue that an esoteric teaching, referred to as the 'True Gnosis', was integrated into early Christian systems, distinct from 'Pseudonymous Gnosis'. They suggest that geometrical principles, especially those relating to higher dimensions and architectural symbolism, were fundamental to this Gnosis. They propose that this hidden knowledge provides a 'locus for miracles' and aligns with advanced mathematical concepts of higher space and the phenomena of life.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter III. The Uses of Gematria.
structure_content.summary: This chapter asserts that Gematria acts as a numerical key to an ancient esoteric teaching, expressing geometrical and mathematical truths applied in architecture and language. It emphasizes Gematria's role in preserving the integrity and deeper meanings of sacred texts, correcting transcriptional errors, and providing a consistent interpretation of theological concepts that are otherwise vague or lost. The authors highlight its utility in reconciling inconsistencies and confirming the divine origin of certain names.

This section applies Gematria to specific examples, illustrating how numbers like EIGHT (888 for ΙΗΣΟΥΣ), 37, 485, 1500 (ΦΩΣ), and 2683 (ΤΟ ΠΛΗΡΩΜΑ ΤΟΥ ΘΕΟΥ) represent significant theological concepts and geometric forms. It discusses the 'Metacubes' (cube-differences like 1, 19, 37) and their relation to Christological names (ΙΗΣΟΥΣ, ΧΡΙΣΤΟΣ, ΜΑΡΙΑΜ) and divine attributes (ΘΕΟΤΗΣ). The chapter connects these numerical values to concepts like Salvation, Light, and the Holy Trinity, often through mathematical operations and geometric proportions.

The Digamma (F*) is discussed as an obsolete Greek letter retained for its numerical value (6) and its later fusion with the 'stau' sign to form 'σταυρος' (The Cross), which has a gematria value of 777 (a multiple of 37), signifying a symbolic connection to the 888 of Jesus. This highlights the intentional retention of numerical values for esoteric purposes even as the alphabet evolved.

This appendix details the numerical properties of 485, identifying it with 'IEOY', 'IOΥΔΑ', 'IΕΣΟΣ', and 'Ό Παναγιος'. It showcases 485 as a number in a geometrical series, integrating roots of 2, 3, and 6, and as a 'Doubly a Square of the Hypothenuse'. It links 485 to diagrams of concentric squares, suggesting its importance in esoteric geometry.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix B. Of the Square and Circle Contained
structure_content.summary: This appendix explores the Gematria of geometric figures (square, circle, lozenge) and their numerical correspondences with theological concepts. Examples include the square perimeter 1270 (Νυμφιος) and circle 998 (Νυμφη), leading to 2268 (Ιησους ο ανθρωπος). It links these to concepts like Messiah, Virgin, Mother, Heavenly City, and the Builder, emphasizing how geometric measures embody spiritual truths.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix C. Names, Epithets, and Types of Christ, Appearing in the Gematria of the Sacred Books as Multiples of 37, Together with Other Examples
structure_content.summary: This extensive appendix provides a catalog of Greek words and phrases, predominantly Christological, whose Gematria values are multiples of 37 (e.g., ΙΗΣΟΥΣ = 37 × 24 = 888, ΧΡΙΣΤΟΣ = 37 × 40 = 1480). It serves as empirical evidence for the system's consistency, showing how terms related to Christ, salvation, and divine attributes align with this specific numerical pattern, suggesting intentional design rather than chance.

This appendix describes the 'Metacube' as a schema representing a cube in flat projection, where points symbolize constituent cubes (visible 37, total 64). It details how these numbers relate to 'ΑΛΗΘΕΙA' (64) and 'Revealed Truth' (37). The schema is applied to the number of Jesus (ΙΗΣΟΥΣ = 888 = 37 × 24), linking hidden and visible cube points to other significant Gematria values like MHTHP (Mother = 456) and ΠNEYMA (Spirit = 576), and theological concepts.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix E. The Decree of the First Mystery
structure_content.summary: This appendix analyzes the Gematria value of 'Ή ΚΕΛΕΥΣΙΣ ΤΟΥ α΄ ΜΥΣΤΗΡΙΟΥ' (3177), interpreting it as a 'triple Pleroma' (3 × 1059). It links 1059 to 'ΠΑΤΡΟΤΗΣ' (Fatherhood) and 'ΜΕΓΑΣ ΠΑΡΑΚΛΗΤΟΣ' (Holy Ghost), and 3177 to 'Α΄ ΜΥΣΤΗΡΙΟΝ' (1179) and 'ΦΥΣΙΣ ΙΗΣΟΥ' (1998). It presents various combinations of this number, suggesting a 'fundamental principle' in Gematria for revealing the Trinity and cosmic order.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix F. Table of the Three Primary Figures of the Μυστηριον
structure_content.summary: This appendix presents a comparative table of Tetrahedron, Octahedron, and Cube as primary figures of the 'Mystery' (Μυστηριον), along with their proportional volumes (10.0, 40.0, 84.9) and Gematria equivalents (e.g., α = 1, μ = 40, ω(μεγα) = 849, μυστηριον = 1178, πεντερημα = 589.2). It shows how these geometric forms and their numerical values are used to express concepts like 'Light', 'Cosmos', and 'Enigma', and relate to Alpha and Omega.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix G. Cabala of the Cosmos
structure_content.summary: This appendix explores the 'Cabala of the Cosmos' using 'κοσμος' (600) as a plastic unit. It demonstrates how multiplying 600 by √2 and √3 yields 'ΜΕΓΑΣ ΚΟΣΜΟΣ' (848/849) and 'ΜΙΚΡΟΣ ΚΟΣΜΟΣ' (1039/1040), respectively. These numerical values are then linked to 'ΜΟΡΦΗ ΤΟΥ ΚΥΡΙΟΥ' (Form of God), 'ΙΗΣΟΥΣ ΚΥΡΙΟΣ ΚΟΣΜOY' (Jesus, Lord of the Universe), asserting that the universe is the 'Word of God' and Man is its reflection.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix H. The Cube of Light
structure_content.summary: This appendix focuses on 'ΦΩΣ' (Light = 1500) and its cube (1500³ = 3375,000,000, simplified to 3375). It connects 3375 to 'Επισκοπος του φωτος' (Bishop of Light) and 'Καταβασις του φωτος' (Descent of Light). It also links 2683 ('First Precept' or 'Sphere of Light') to 3375 through geometric proportions, demonstrating how Gematria describes the creation and manifestation of light through numerical and geometric relationships.

structure_content.chapter_title: Supplement I. On the Symbolism of Numbers.
structure_content.summary: This supplement discusses the historical evolution of number symbolism, distinguishing pure geometrical/mathematical significance from later superstitious or magical attributions. It advocates for a rigorous, systematic approach to Gematria, emphasizing the need to avoid assigning singularly 'good' or 'evil' meanings to individual numbers. The authors highlight a 'polarity of opposites' found in numbers (e.g., Δικαια vs. Αδικια = 46), ensuring balanced interpretation.

This supplement argues that geometry provides a 'higher language' for expressing spiritual ideas and universal truths, akin to the role of architecture. It asserts that human thought itself is geometrical and that geometric forms, with their inherent symmetry and immutable relations, reveal profound truths more effectively than words alone. The authors imply that Jesus taught such geometric principles, making geometry a sacred study for understanding the 'Great Verities'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Supplement III. The Geometric Cubit as a Basis of Proportion in the Plans of Mediaeval Buildings.
structure_content.summary: This supplement proposes a theory that mediaeval builders employed geometric systems ('pariquadrato' and 'trigono') to achieve precise proportions, particularly reproducing the 'Rhombus of two equilateral triangles' (Vesica Piscis). It discusses ancient measures like the 'Geometric Cubit' (e.g., 20.78 inches, based on 1:√3 ratio) as fundamental units derived from terrestrial measures and suggests that these proportions were imbued with sacred symbolism in architectural design.

key_concepts.definition: A system for uncovering hidden meanings, doctrinal significance, and geometric relationships within sacred texts by assigning numerical values to letters and words. This method reveals 'aeonial relationships' and geometric formulae embedded in language.

The mystical interpretation system, specifically applying Gematria to Greek and Hebrew texts to decode divine mysteries. It integrates numerical, geometrical, and theological concepts to unveil a coherent system of divine wisdom.

A higher, inward revelation or deeper wisdom that the Apostolic Church supposedly possessed. It is understood through Gematria and geometric symbolism, distinct from 'Pseudonymous Gnosis', and provides insight into spiritual powers and the nature of the cosmos.

The connections and principles pertaining to eternal or divine entities (Aeons), which are expressed and understood through the numerical and geometric patterns revealed by Gematria. These relationships are often conceived in a geometric sense.

Geometrical figures or schemata representing clusters of points, particularly corresponding to the 'cube-differences' (e.g., 1, 19, 37). These are used to symbolize foundational numbers in Gematria, especially those related to Christ's names and cosmic structures, illustrating visible and hidden aspects of truth.

A geometric figure formed by the intersection of two equal circles, symbolizing the genesis of the Logos. It embodies key proportions (e.g., breadth to length ratio of 1:√3) used in sacred architecture and represents fundamental principles of creation and manifestation.

A precise unit of measurement (e.g., 20.78 inches) derived from fundamental geometric principles (such as the Mean Proportional between the foot and yard). This cubit, and its associated ratios, formed the basis of proportion in ancient and mediaeval sacred buildings, reflecting an underlying cosmic order.

The ultimate source and governing intelligence of the universe, whose thoughts are expressed as numbers and geometric forms. This wisdom is reflected in the construction of the physical and moral world and is accessible through the Gematria system.

Irrational numbers (e.g., √2, √3) that are expressed in integral terms through Gematria. They represent fundamental geometric relations and are associated with 'Formative Principles' or 'Active Powers' that bring the visible Universe into manifestation.

practical_system.description: The practical system is a method of textual and numerical analysis to uncover a hidden 'Gnosis'. It involves calculating the Gematria (numerical value) of Greek and Hebrew words and phrases from sacred texts. These values are then cross-referenced with other numbers, examined for mathematical relationships (sums, products, multiples of significant numbers like 37), and interpreted through geometric analogies (e.g., cubes, squares, circles, Vesica Piscis, proportions like 1:√3). The goal is to reveal underlying 'aeonial relationships' and 'Formative Principles' that connect divine names, theological doctrines, and cosmic structures. This 'decoding' process allows practitioners to access a deeper, geometric understanding of divine wisdom, as believed to be embedded by ancient builders and religious teachers.
tools: Greek and Hebrew alphabets with their numerical equivalents (e.g., provided on page 6 for Greek).
Sacred texts: Coptic Gnostic Books (Pistis Sophia, Books of IEOU), Greek New Testament, Old Testament (Hebrew Qabalah implicitly).
Mathematical knowledge: Proficiency in arithmetic, geometry (Euclidean constructions, understanding of proportions, roots, and three-dimensional forms like cubes, tetrahedrons, octahedrons).
Reference tables/lists of Gematria values and their correspondences (e.g., Appendix C for multiples of 37).
rituals: Gematria Calculation: Assigning numerical values to Greek and Hebrew letters within words and phrases, then summing these values.

Numerical Analysis: Identifying mathematical relationships (multiples, sums, roots, proportions) between calculated Gematria values and other significant numbers (e.g., 37 as a foundational Christos series number, 485 for IEOY/Panagios, 888 for Jesus).
Geometric Interpretation: Mapping numerical values to geometric forms and proportions (e.g., KΗΦΑΣ=729=9x9x9 as a cube, ΤΟ ΘΥΣΙΑΣΤΗΡΙΟΝ=1728=12x12x12 as a cube, 1:√3 ratio for the Vesica Piscis).

Theological Synthesis: Integrating these numerical and geometric insights to interpret Christian doctrines and Gnostic teachings, aiming to recover the 'Key of Knowledge' and 'Mysteries of the Faith'.
Symbolic Correlation: Connecting Gematria values to cosmological concepts, divine names, and architectural symbolism (e.g., the 'Geometric Cubit' in building plans).

relevant_quotes.text: '... numbers are the thoughts of God ... The Divine Wisdom is reflected in the numbers impressed upon all things ... the construction of the physical and moral world alike is based upon eternal numbers.'

SHOWING THE PRESENCE OF A SYSTEM OF TEACHING BY MEANS OF THE DOCTRINAL SIGNIFICANCE OF NUMBERS, BY WHICH THE HOLY NAMES ARE CLEARLY SEEN TO REPRESENT AEONIAL RELATIONSHIPS WHICH CAN BE CONCEIVED IN A GEOMETRIC SENSE AND ARE CAPABLE OF A TYPICAL EXPRESSION OF THAT ORDER.

It was a cipher or code expression according to a well known system which prevailed both in Hebrew and in Greek, and there is good reason for supposing that a great deal of secret information of a political or commercial sort was sent under cover of such a code. But that was not all. The name of the code was ΓΕΜΑΤΡΙΑ or ΓΑΜΕΤΡΙΑ, the latter word being a recognised variant of ΓΕΩΜΕΤΡΙΑ, and it has become clear that this code-method was actually used in these books to record and to memorise geometrical formulae.
The true proportion of the double triangle is as 1 in breadth to the square root of 3 in length, or as 1 : 1·73205.

The authors believe that the Key may be recovered, and the subject-matter of their work already tends to shew that the Apostolic Church possessed a real GNOSIS which made the Faith a great reality and joy to the intelligence, and gave an insight into the nature of the Spiritual powers that were exercised.

But Number and Geometrical form are aeonially true and constant in their relations, and a system of representation of natural truth having for its vehicle a carefully co-ordinated series of number symbols, in their turn expressive of definite relations of form, would, if it could be practically contrived and interwoven with the text of Scriptural books, have a most conservative effect.

Geometry is therefore a sacred study, the Language of the Great Verities, and it follows that any language built upon Geometry will contain more than at first meets the eye, and will be capable of a limitless power of expression, because its rational terms are eternal in nature, and infinite.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism as it attempts to establish a systematic, rational (mathematical/geometrical) foundation for Gematria, moving beyond mere numerological superstition. It directly links Gematria to the Qabalah, Gnosticism, Hermeticism, and even early Christian doctrines, suggesting a cohesive underlying 'True Gnosis'. For practitioners, it offers a detailed methodology for textual analysis to uncover deeper layers of meaning in sacred texts, viewing them not just as theological narratives but as encoded blueprints of cosmic and divine principles. Its focus on geometric proportions in architecture also provides a unique bridge between abstract mystical concepts and tangible earthly manifestations.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists of academic researchers and serious practitioners in Western Esotericism, Occultism, Qabalah, Gnosticism, Hermeticism, and theological studies with a strong interest in numerical and geometric symbolism. The dense, technical language, reliance on Greek transliterations, and complex mathematical/geometric examples (e.g., 'cube-differences', 'incommensurable quantities', 'Geometric Cubit' derivations) necessitate a high level of background knowledge in these fields.
